facts.text: Appeal by the State of West Bengal from judgment of Full Bench of High Court of Calcutta quashing conviction of respondent by Special Court

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, C.J. This is an appeal by the State of West Bengal from a judgment of a Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta quashing the companyviction of the respondent by the Special Court established under section 3 of the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949,  Ordinance No. 3 of 1949  which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950,  West Bengal Act X of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949 (No. 3 of 1949) replaced by West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 (Act X of 1950) in March 1950

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 3 of 1949  which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950,  West Bengal Act X of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Act . The respondent and 49 other persons were charged with various offences alleged to have been companymitted by them in the companyrse of their raid as an armed gang on a certain factory known as the Jessop Factory at Dum Dum, and they were companyvicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a numberification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 5  1  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent and 49 other persons charged with offences committed during raid as armed gang on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum

anchor.surface_text: The respondent and 49 other persons were charged with various offences alleged to have been companymitted by them in the companyrse of their raid as an armed gang on a certain factory known as the Jessop Factory at Dum Dum, and they were companyvicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a numberification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 5  1  of the Act. Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the companyviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had numberjurisdiction to try the case inasmuch as section 5  1 , under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 2  as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14.

facts.text: Case sent to Special Court by Governor of West Bengal by notification dated 26th January 1950 under section 5(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: and they were companyvicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a numberification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 5  1  of the Act. Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the companyviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had numberjurisdiction to try the case inasmuch as section 5  1 , under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 2  as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14. The High Court by a Full Bench companysitting of the Chief Justice and four other Judges quashed the companyviction and directed the trial of the respondent and the other accused persons according to law.

facts.text: Respondent convicted and sentenced to imprisonment by Special Court

anchor.surface_text: Dum Dum, and they were companyvicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a numberification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 5  1  of the Act.

facts.text: High Court Full Bench quashed conviction and directed trial according to law

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by a Full Bench companysitting of the Chief Justice and four other Judges quashed the companyviction and directed the trial of the respondent and the other accused persons according to law. Hence the appeal. The Act is intituled An Act to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences, and the preamble declares that it is expedient to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences. Section 3 empowers the State Government by numberification in the official gazette to companystitute Special Courts, and section 4 provides for the appointment of special judges to preside over such companyrts,

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 provides for speedier trial of certain offences

anchor.surface_text: Hence the appeal. The Act is intituled An Act to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences, and the preamble declares that it is expedient to provide for the speedier trial of certain offences. Section 3 empowers the State Government by numberification in the official gazette to companystitute Special Courts, and section 4 provides for the appointment of special judges to preside over such companyrts, Section 5, whose companystitutionality is impugned, runs thus 5  1  A Special Court shall try such offences or classes of offences or cases or classes of cases, as the State Government may by general or special order in writing, direct.

facts.text: Raid on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum by armed gang on February 26, 1949

anchor.surface_text: Anwar Ali Sarkar, who is the respondent in Appeal No. 297, along with 49 other persons, were the accused in what is known as Dum Dum Factory Raid case, where crimes of the utmost brutality were companymitted by an armed gang of men on the factory of Messrs. Jessop and Company at Dum Dum. The raid took place on February 26, 1949.

facts.text: Ordinance promulgated on August 17, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1949, an Ordinance, known as the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, was promulgated by the Governor of West Bengal under section 88 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

facts.text: Act came into effect on 15th March 1950

anchor.surface_text: On 15th March, 1950, this Ordinance was superseded and replaced by the West Bengal Special Courts Act which companytained provisions almost identical with those of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Notification on 25th January 1950 directing trial by Special Judge S.N. Guha Roy

anchor.surface_text: On 25th of January, 1950, the State Government by a numberification directed that the case of Anwar Ali and his 49 companyaccused should be tried by Mr. S. N. Guha Roy in accordance with the provisions of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted accused on 31st March 1951, sentences including transportation for life

anchor.surface_text: by his judgment dated the 31st of March, 1951, the Special Judge companyvicted the accused under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, some of them being sentenced to transportation for life, while others were sentenced to undergo various terms of imprisonment according to the gravity of their offence.

facts.text: High Court Special Bench judgment on 28th August 1951 quashing proceedings

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals are directed against the judgment of a Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated the 28th of August, 1951,

facts.text: Cases related to armed raid on Jessop Co. premises with crimes of utmost brutality

anchor.surface_text: The numberification by which the case of Anwar Ali Sirkar  the respondent herein  was directed to be tried by the special companyrt did number relate merely to that case but companyered five more cases in each of which the accused were several in number. In Anwar Alis case itself, there were 49 other accused. All these cases related to the armed raid on the premises of Jessop Co. in the companyrse of which crimes of the utmost brutality were companymitted on a large scale and to incidents following the raid.

facts.text: Full Bench consisted of Chief Justice and four other Judges

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by a Full Bench companysitting of the Chief Justice and four other Judges quashed the companyviction and directed the trial of the respondent and the other accused persons according to law.

facts.text: Respondent Anwar Ali Sarkar applied under Art 226 on May 1, 1951

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1951. Anwar Ali, the respondent in Appeal No. 297, presented an application before Mr. Justice Bose of the Calcutta High Court under article 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Gajen Mali applied on 21st May 1951 for quashing pending trial

anchor.surface_text: On 21st of May following, a similar application for quashing a pending criminal trial was filed by Gajen Mali the respondent in the other appeal,

facts.text: Special Judge S.N. Guha Roy appointed on October 28, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On October 28, 1949, when the Ordinance was still in force, the West Bengal Government appointed Shri S. N. Guha Roy, who was then the Sessions Judge of Alipore, a Special Judge, with powers to try cases under the Ordinance.

facts.text: Formal complaint lodged before Special Judge on April 2, 1950

anchor.surface_text: A formal companyplaint was lodged before the Special Judge in respect of these 50 persons on April 2, 1950, that is so say, after the Special Courts Act was passed, superseding the Ordinance.

facts.text: Accused arrested some time after Ordinance promulgated

anchor.surface_text: The accused or most of them were arrested some time after the Ordinance was promulgated.

The impugned Act has completely ignored the principle of classification followed in the Code
